body_html:
You can initialize the variables using function global_variables_initializer().
Also refer this.
This should pass:
import tensorflow as tf
get_session = tf.keras.backend.get_session
a = tf.Variable([[0.5, 0., 1.], [2., 0., -1.]])
with tf.Session() as sess:
sess.run(tf.global_variables_initializer())
print(tf.add(a, a).eval(session=get_session()))
body_text:
You can initialize the variables using function global_variables_initializer().
Also refer this.
This should pass:
import tensorflow as tf
get_session = tf.keras.backend.get_session
a = tf.Variable([[0.5, 0., 1.], [2., 0., -1.]])
with tf.Session() as sess:
sess.run(tf.global_variables_initializer())
print(tf.add(a, a).eval(session=get_session()))
body:
You can initialize the variables using function [global_variables_initializer()](https://www.tensorflow.org/api_docs/python/tf/Variable).
Also refer [this](https://www.tensorflow.org/api_docs/python/tf/initializers/global_variables).
This should pass:
import tensorflow as tf
get_session = tf.keras.backend.get_session
a = tf.Variable([[0.5, 0., 1.], [2., 0., -1.]])
with tf.Session() as sess: 
    sess.run(tf.global_variables_initializer())
    print(tf.add(a, a).eval(session=get_session()))
